Award.AwardTitle: NSF/CBMS Regional Conference in the Mathematical Sciences-Deformation Theory of Algebras and Modules- May 16-20, 2011
Award.AbstractNarration:
In recent years deformation of algebraic and topological structures has given rise to important structures such as quantum groups, vertex algebras, and homotopy Lie algebras which in turn have important connections with other areas of mathematics and physics. The representation theory of quantum groups and vertex algebras are better understood than the representation theory of homotopy Lie algebras. An NSF/ CBMS regional conference on "Deformation Theory of Algebras and Modules" is proposed to be held at North Carolina State University during the week of May 16 - May 20, 2011 with Professor Martin Markl of the Mathematical Institute of the Czech Academy as the principal lecturer who will deliver ten lectures on deformations of algebras and modules. Professor Markl will shed new light on these seemingly unrelated algebraic structures. This in turn will generate discussions among participating algebraists, topologists as well as mathematical physicists to explore new frontiers of research in deformation theory. It is hoped that this will lead to research collaborations among participants. In particular, it may result in a better understanding of the representations of homotopy Lie algebras.

A major objective of this conference is to foster new collaborations among algebraists and topologists working on various aspects of deformation theory. The proposed lecture series will be of immense educational value to the participating graduate students and young researchers from universities in the southeastern region of USA. Furthermore, this lecture series will help enhance the research collaborations between researchers in USA and Eastern Europe, and provide international exposure to participating US graduate students and junior researchers. It will also help attract strong graduate students from Eastern Europe to NCSU and other US universities in the southeastern region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CBMS conference on “Deformation Theory of Algebras and Modules” organized by Kailash C. Misra and Thomas Lada was held at North Carolina State University during May 16-20, 2011. It was attended by 60 participants including 33 graduate students, 13 women and 4 underrepresented minorities.  Out of these 60 participants 34 participants including 16 graduate students were supported by the grant from the National Science Foundation for this conference. In this conference, Professor Martin Markl of the Mathematical Institute of the Czech Academy gave a series of 10 talks on deformation theory of algebras and modules. 

Professor Markl’s talks were complemented by five invited talks given by Professors Murray Gerstenhaber, Haisheng Li, Sarah Witherspoon, Anthony Giaquinto and Alexander Voronov during the afternoon sessions.  Participant interaction was encouraged during the informal discussion sessions in the afternoons.

Furthermore, the coffee breaks between lectures provided ample time for participants to interact with the principal speaker and other speakers. Two social events (one reception and one dinner) were organized during the conference where the graduate students and junior researchers interacted with the senior participants at a personal level. The participants were housed in an airconditioned on-campus dormitory in close proximity of the conference site. The organizers arranged complimentary airport pick-up and drop-off service for all participants. On the last day of the conference the photo of the participants was taken and the participants were requested to fill out an anonymous survey. In the survey participants were asked to comment on the scientific program and the over all organization of this conference.  The organizers were humbled by the overwhelmingly positive comments by the participants.
